intro: Adenodiscus mexicanus, commonly known as Mexican spiderflower, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in clusters. Its leaves are ovate and have a rough texture, while its roots are fibrous and often used in traditional medicine. Adenodiscus mexicanus thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often found in disturbed soils and open areas.
